completedText: Congratulations! You found and learned about the 9 Living Room Triggers and Ways to Avoid!! Now you are going into the Bathroom. Enjoy finding and learning!!

postText:
Plants can grow mold in the soil.

  • Mold are sometimes microscopic (can’t be seen with the eye) fungi or spores that live on plants. These spores can go into the air and be breathed in.. Mold can be an allergy trigger and can cause symptoms to flare for some people with asthma. Mold grows in areas of moisture and high humidity. Common areas of mold are: bathrooms, basements, potted plants, and areas of indoor water leaks. Outdoors, mold is commonly found in soil & leaves

How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Maintain low indoor humidity, Best between 30-50% relative humidity. Humidity levels can be measured by hygrometers found at local hardware stores.
  • Install dehumidifier if needed.
  • Do not use humidifiers or vaporizers excessively as they can be a source of moisture and mold growth.
  • Clean & remove mold promptly
  • Remove or reduce the number of indoor plants. Only use plants that do not need misting.
  • Do not over water plants. When soil is moist do not water. Use a tool to check if the plant needs water.
  • Limit or avoid outdoor exposure to molds & leaves
targets.Name: Plant
targets.hint: I grow in & on moist places like soil

postText:
Physical activity can trigger asthma symptoms for some people.

It is also known as exercise-induced bronchoconstriction/asthma (EIB/EIA)

It is described as problems with breathing during &/or after exercise.

Exercising in extreme air temperatures or poor air quality can worsen this for some people.

To stay healthy it is important to exercise. 

Some people with asthma are prescribed medication to treat these symptoms so they can tolerate exercise. 

      How to avoid or reduce this trigger causing asthma

  • Talk to the health care provider to make an exercise plan.
  • Some people with asthma may need to take medication that helps keep their asthma in control when they exercise.
  • If premedication is prescribed, make sure it is available & taken as directed before all physical activities. (See the example on the backpack, now prepared with an inhaler and spacer)
  • Caution when exercise is outdoors, change in weather or airborne allergens & air quality can affect asthma too.
targets.Name: Sports
targets.hint: I can take your breath away if you’re not careful

postText: This is a girl. She is not an asthma trigger.
This is a girl. She is not an asthma trigger.
targets.Name: Girl

postText:
Smoking/vaping (Tobacco - cigarettes, e-cigarettes, cigars, pipes, other) is unhealthy for everyone, especially people with asthma. It can be an inhaled irritant and trigger asthma for some people.

  • Smoke/vapor from tobacco travels through the air and can be found both indoors and outdoors.
  • Smoke/vapor can leave behind the tiniest of particles which can be found on clothes, all household surfaces and car interiors.
  • If You Can Smell Smoke/Vapors, You Can Be BREATHING IN SMOKE/VAPORS!

Secondhand smoke/vapors is the smoke that comes off a burning item such as a cigarette.

  • They can be breathed in by another person nearby the smoker and vapor.
  • They contain nicotine, heavy metals, particles, toxic chemicals and tobacco that can harm the lungs.
  • They can trigger asthma symptoms.

Third hand smoke/vapors are the tiniest parts (residue) of the smoked/vaped tobacco cigarette, e-cigarette, cigar or pipe that remains after it has been put out.

  • They can contain cancer causing substances.
  • They can cling to a person’s hair, skin, and clothes.
  • They can be found on surfaces like furniture, drapes, bedding, carpets, walls, windows and toys.
  • They can be found in dust.
  • They can be found in the interior of cars.

How to avoid or reduce this trigger: 

The only way to protect nonsmokers from third hand smoke/vapors is to create a smoke/vaping-free environment

• Encourage all smokers/vapors to seek help to quit

• For those who continue to smoke/vape:  Always smoke/vape outside far away from the home, car, etc.

• Use cover up clothing, pull back hair, wear a hat while smoking/vaping outdoors and leave that clothing outside the home

• Change your clothes, wash hands and face, and rinse mouth after smoking/vaping
targets.Name: Man
targets.hint: I have a health warning on my label

postText:
Pollens can be sources of allergen and may trigger asthma symptoms in some people. They can be airborne, outdoor as well as indoor, They can deposit on household surfaces and car interiors and be a source of allergen exposure.

 

How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Keep windows closed especially during high airborne pollen days & hours of the day commonly more easily spread through the air & breeze.
  • Do not dry Laundry outdoors
  • Limit outdoor exposure during high pollen times. Remove clothing worn outdoors before using indoor furniture & bedroom areas. Shower after outdoor activity 
  • Damp dust all surfaces often in all rooms to minimize airborne pollens.
  • Use a vacuum with a HEPA filter to clean pollen dust
  • Use window filters, and air conditioning, to filter out pollen airborne in the home.
targets.Name: Window
targets.hint: I can fly for miles and land all over your stuff

postText:
Furry pets are a common allergy trigger and can cause symptoms to flare for some people with asthma. (EX: Dog, Cats).

They can spread allergens in a home on surfaces and in the air.

How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • If allergic to pets, best to remove from home.
  • Keep furry pets out of bedrooms.
  • Vacuum frequently
  • Wash furry pets often
targets.Name: Dog
targets.hint: I’m a best friend for some, not so cute if you’re allergic to me

postText:
How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

Dust mites are found in furniture made from fabric that is stuffed, or has padding etc. (Upholstered furniture) Dust mites can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma. Dust mites are microscopic in size (can’t be seen with the eye), they live in places and items made of thick fibers, such as (Bedding, carpets pillow, sofa, rugs and stuffed toys).  

 

How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • When possible, consider replacing furniture with a sealed material (non-fabric) such as leather, wood, plastic, vinyl etc.
  • Vacuum (HEPA filter vacuum) furniture often
  • Avoid sleeping on furniture made from fabric and stuffing like a sofa
  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%.
targets.Name: Couch
targets.hint: I’m a place to sit & relax

postText:
Wood fireplaces & wood burning stoves makes smoke that causes indoor air pollution. This inhaled irritant can trigger asthma symptoms for some people

How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Avoid using a wood fireplace, wood burning stoves indoors.
  • Look into cleaner heating appliances

When a fireplace or wood burning stove is used: 

  • Make sure your stove or fireplace doesn't leak wood smoke
    • Make sure the stove or fireplace is well-vented
    • Only burn clean, dry wood. Other materials can produce smoke and fumes that may be toxic
    • Consider use of Pellet stoves, according to EPA they are least polluting
    • Ensure professional cleaning & inspection of fireplace, chimney, wood burning stoves are done yearly or more often
    • Operate the system according to manufacturer’s instructions
targets.Name: Fire

postText:
Dust mites are found in rugs and carpeting. 

Dust mites can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

Dust mites are microscopic in size (can’t be seen with the eye), they live in places and items made of thick fibers, such as (Bedding, carpets pillow, sofa, rugs and stuffed toys).   

How to avoid reduce this trigger:

  • Remove rugs from home
  • Replace carpeting with flooring (Ex: Tile, wood) that can be damp mopped often.
  • If you must retain the carpet, use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA) or a central vacuum cleaner.
  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%.
targets.Name: Carpet

postText:
House dust is a common allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

Dust can cause asthma symptoms or make asthma get worse.

House dust contains many tiny particles, some of which can be from pollen, mold,pet dander & hair, dust mites, and pests.

Vacuum cleaners contain dust particles and can spread the dust.around a room or in the air.

House dust: How to avoid or reduce this trigger

  • Vacuum when the person with asthma is NOT at home because dust from vacuuming can be spread back into the air.
  • Use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA filter vacuum) on carpet and fabric-covered furniture to reduce dust build-up and reduce the amount of dust coming out of the vacuum.
  • Be careful when emptying the dirt from the vacuum cleaner to avoid the collected dust spreading in the air.
  • Central heating and air conditioning systems may help control dust, change filters often.
  • Wipe away dust on all surfaces with a damp cloth and vacuum once a week.
  • Reduce clutter to help reduce dust.
  • Consider using a HEPA air purifier if airborne dust is a problem.

                      (AVOID IONIC & OZONE PRODUCING TYPES)
targets.Name: Dust
targets.hint: some say I'm spread around by a pixie, others say I'm a bunny
